intro: Acacia pseudowightii, commonly known as the white acacia, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is a small, shrub-like tree that typically grows in dry, sandy soils. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in cylindrical clusters, which bloom during the dry season. Its leaves are bipinnate, consisting of numerous tiny leaflets, and it has a distinctive, knobby root system. Acacia pseudowightii is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat.

It is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions, particularly in sandy soils. This species thrives in open woodlands and shrublands, often along watercourses or in areas with seasonal rainfall. It is well adapted to the harsh conditions of the Australian outback. Its distribution is largely limited to the inland regions of northern Australia.
